hub.title: Nutrition & Brain Optimization
hub.description: What you eat affects how you feel. Discover evidence-based nutrition strategies to support your mental health and optimize brain function.

disclaimer.title: Medical Disclaimer
disclaimer.text: Nutritional information is educational and not a substitute for medical advice. Always consult with your healthcare provider before making significant dietary changes or starting supplements, especially if you take medications.

depression.title: Foods for Depression
depression.description: Nutrition strategies to support mood and mental health recovery

anxiety.title: Foods for Anxiety
anxiety.description: Dietary approaches to reduce anxiety and promote calm

focus.title: Foods for Focus
focus.description: Brain-healthy foods to support concentration and cognitive function

supplements.title: Supplements Guide
supplements.description: Evidence-based supplements for mental health support

resources.title: Downloadable Resources
resources.description: Free guides to support your nutrition journey

groceryList.title: Mood-Boosting Grocery List
groceryList.description: Foods to stock for mental health support

common.medicalDisclaimerText: This information is educational and not a substitute for professional medical advice. Always consult with your healthcare provider before making significant dietary changes, especially if you are taking medications.

depression.title: Foods for Depression
depression.metaDescription: Evidence-based nutrition strategies for depression. Learn which foods support mood, omega-3 benefits, gut-brain connection, and practical meal plans for mental health.

intro.p1: Research increasingly shows that nutrition plays a significant role in mental health. While food alone cannot cure depression, a nutrient-rich diet can support brain function, stabilize mood, and complement other treatments like therapy and medication.
intro.p2: The gut-brain axis—the bidirectional communication between your digestive system and brain—means what you eat directly affects neurotransmitter production, inflammation levels, and overall brain health.

fattyFish.title: Fatty Fish
fattyFish.description: Salmon, sardines, mackerel, anchovies are rich in omega-3 fatty acids (EPA and DHA), which reduce brain inflammation and support neurotransmitter function. Research shows omega-3s can reduce depression symptoms.

leafyGreens.title: Leafy Greens
leafyGreens.description: Spinach, kale, Swiss chard, collard greens provide folate (vitamin B9), which is essential for producing serotonin and dopamine. Low folate levels are associated with increased depression risk.
leafyGreens.serving: Include 1-2 cups daily in salads, smoothies, or cooked dishes.

nutsSeeds.title: Nuts and Seeds
nutsSeeds.description: Walnuts, flaxseeds, chia seeds, almonds contain omega-3s, zinc, and magnesium. Walnuts are particularly beneficial for brain health and mood regulation.
nutsSeeds.serving: A handful (1 oz) daily as a snack or added to meals.

berries.title: Berries
berries.description: Blueberries, strawberries, blackberries are rich in antioxidants that protect the brain from oxidative stress and inflammation, both linked to depression.
berries.serving: ½-1 cup daily, fresh or frozen.

wholeGrains.title: Whole Grains
wholeGrains.description: Quinoa, oats, brown rice, whole wheat provide B vitamins and complex carbohydrates that stabilize blood sugar and support serotonin production.
wholeGrains.serving: Choose whole grains over refined grains for sustained energy.

fermentedFoods.title: Fermented Foods
fermentedFoods.description: Yogurt, kefir, kimchi, sauerkraut, kombucha contain probiotics that support gut health. A healthy gut microbiome is crucial for neurotransmitter production—90% of serotonin is made in the gut.

darkChocolate.title: Dark Chocolate
darkChocolate.description: 70%+ cocoa content contains flavonoids and compounds that may boost mood and reduce stress hormones. Dark chocolate also provides magnesium.
darkChocolate.serving: 1-2 small squares (about 1 oz) as an occasional treat.

omega3.title: Omega-3 Fatty Acids (EPA/DHA)
omega3.description: Reduce inflammation, support neurotransmitter function, and improve brain cell membrane fluidity. Multiple studies show EPA supplementation reduces depression symptoms.
omega3.sources: Sources: Fatty fish, walnuts, flaxseeds, chia seeds

bVitamins.title: B Vitamins (B6, B12, Folate)
bVitamins.description: Essential for producing serotonin, dopamine, and norepinephrine. Deficiencies in B vitamins are common in depression.
bVitamins.sources: Sources: Leafy greens, legumes, whole grains, eggs, fish, poultry

vitaminD.title: Vitamin D
vitaminD.description: Vitamin D receptors are found throughout the brain. Deficiency is linked to seasonal affective disorder (SAD) and major depression.
vitaminD.sources: Sources: Sunlight exposure, fatty fish, fortified dairy, egg yolks, mushrooms

magnesium.title: Magnesium
magnesium.description: Calms the nervous system, regulates stress response, and supports neurotransmitter function. Low magnesium is associated with increased depression and anxiety.
magnesium.sources: Sources: Leafy greens, nuts, seeds, whole grains, dark chocolate, legumes

zinc.title: Zinc
zinc.description: Modulates brain and body response to stress. Zinc deficiency is observed in depression, and supplementation may enhance antidepressant effects.
zinc.sources: Sources: Oysters, beef, pumpkin seeds, lentils, cashews

tryptophan.title: Tryptophan
tryptophan.description: An amino acid that is the precursor to serotonin, the "feel-good" neurotransmitter.
tryptophan.sources: Sources: Turkey, chicken, eggs, cheese, tofu, pumpkin seeds, oats

processedSugar.title: Processed Foods High in Sugar
processedSugar.description: Causes blood sugar spikes and crashes that worsen mood instability. High sugar intake is associated with increased depression risk and inflammation.
processedSugar.advice: Limit candy, soda, baked goods, and processed snacks.

caffeine.title: Excessive Caffeine
caffeine.description: While moderate caffeine can improve alertness, excessive intake (>400mg/day, ~4 cups coffee) can worsen anxiety, disrupt sleep, and cause mood crashes.
caffeine.advice: Monitor your tolerance; some people with depression are more caffeine-sensitive.

alcohol.title: Alcohol
alcohol.description: A central nervous system depressant that disrupts sleep, depletes B vitamins, and interferes with antidepressant medications. Chronic use worsens depression.
alcohol.advice: Limit or avoid alcohol, especially when experiencing depressive episodes.

transFats.title: Trans Fats & Highly Processed Oils
transFats.description: Found in fried foods, margarine, and many packaged snacks. Trans fats increase inflammation and are linked to higher depression rates.
transFats.advice: Choose olive oil, avocado oil, or coconut oil instead.

studies.gutBrain: Gut-brain axis and mental health (emerging research)

items.yogurt: Greek yogurt with strawberries, chia seeds, and sliced almonds
items.omelet: Spinach and mushroom omelet with whole grain toast
items.smoothie: Smoothie with kale, banana, berries, flaxseeds, and almond milk

items.salmon: Grilled salmon salad with mixed greens, avocado, and olive oil dressing
items.quinoa: Quinoa bowl with roasted vegetables, chickpeas, and tahini sauce
items.wrap: Turkey and avocado wrap with whole wheat tortilla and vegetables
items.soup: Lentil soup with kale and whole grain bread

items.bakedSalmon: Baked salmon with roasted sweet potato and steamed broccoli
items.chicken: Grilled chicken with quinoa and sautéed spinach
items.sardines: Sardines over mixed greens with cherry tomatoes and olive oil
items.tofu: Tofu stir-fry with brown rice and colorful vegetables

anxiety.title: Foods for Anxiety
anxiety.metaDescription: Foods that reduce anxiety naturally. Learn about magnesium-rich foods, calming nutrients, gut-brain connection, and meal plans to manage anxiety symptoms.

intro.p1: Nutrition plays a crucial role in managing anxiety. Certain foods can help calm the nervous system, stabilize blood sugar levels, and support neurotransmitter balance—all of which influence anxiety levels.
intro.p2: While dietary changes alone may not eliminate anxiety, they can significantly reduce symptoms and complement other treatments like therapy, medication, and stress management techniques.

fattyFish.title: Fatty Fish
fattyFish.description: Salmon, sardines, mackerel are rich in omega-3 fatty acids, which reduce inflammation and have been shown to decrease anxiety symptoms in multiple studies.

leafyGreens.title: Dark Leafy Greens
leafyGreens.description: Spinach, kale, Swiss chard are high in magnesium, a natural muscle relaxant that calms the nervous system. Magnesium deficiency is linked to increased anxiety.
leafyGreens.serving: Include 1-2 cups daily in salads, smoothies, or sautéed.

chamomile.title: Chamomile Tea
chamomile.description: Contains apigenin, an antioxidant that binds to brain receptors promoting relaxation and reducing anxiety. Chamomile has been used for centuries as a natural calming agent.
chamomile.serving: 1-2 cups daily, especially in the evening.

almonds.title: Almonds
almonds.description: Rich in magnesium and vitamin E, both of which support stress reduction. Almonds also provide healthy fats that stabilize blood sugar and mood.
almonds.serving: A handful (1 oz) as a snack or added to meals.

avocados.title: Avocados
avocados.description: Loaded with B vitamins (especially B6) that support neurotransmitter production and stress response. The healthy fats promote brain health and stabilize mood.
avocados.serving: ½ avocado daily in salads, sandwiches, or smoothies.

turkey.title: Turkey
turkey.description: Contains tryptophan, an amino acid that produces serotonin—a neurotransmitter that promotes calm and well-being.
turkey.serving: Lean protein at lunch or dinner.

bananas.title: Bananas
bananas.description: Provide vitamin B6, which helps produce serotonin, and potassium, which regulates blood pressure during stress. The natural sugars offer quick energy without a crash.
bananas.serving: 1-2 bananas daily as a snack or in smoothies.

complexCarbs.title: Complex Carbohydrates
complexCarbs.description: Oats, quinoa, sweet potatoes, brown rice promote steady serotonin release and stabilize blood sugar, preventing the mood swings associated with anxiety.
complexCarbs.serving: Choose whole grains over refined carbs for sustained calm.

magnesium.title: Magnesium
magnesium.description: The "relaxation mineral" that calms the nervous system, relaxes muscles, and supports GABA production (the brain's calming neurotransmitter). Magnesium deficiency is common in anxiety disorders.
magnesium.sources: Sources: Leafy greens, almonds, cashews, black beans, dark chocolate, avocados

bVitamins.title: B Vitamins (B6, B12, Folate)
bVitamins.description: Essential for producing neurotransmitters that regulate mood and stress response. B vitamins are depleted during chronic stress, creating a cycle of increased anxiety.
bVitamins.sources: Sources: Turkey, chicken, fish, eggs, leafy greens, legumes, whole grains

omega3.title: Omega-3 Fatty Acids
omega3.description: Reduce inflammation and support brain cell membrane function. Research shows omega-3 supplementation reduces anxiety symptoms, particularly in those with high inflammation.
omega3.sources: Sources: Fatty fish, walnuts, flaxseeds, chia seeds, hemp seeds

probiotics.title: Probiotics
probiotics.description: Support the gut-brain axis. Studies show specific probiotic strains reduce anxiety by producing GABA and regulating the stress response through the vagus nerve.
probiotics.sources: Sources: Yogurt, kefir, kimchi, sauerkraut, kombucha, miso

lTheanine.title: L-Theanine
lTheanine.description: An amino acid found in green tea that promotes relaxation without sedation. L-theanine increases alpha brain waves associated with calm alertness.
lTheanine.sources: Sources: Green tea, black tea, certain mushrooms

antioxidants.title: Antioxidants
antioxidants.description: Protect the brain from oxidative stress caused by chronic anxiety. Antioxidant-rich diets are associated with lower anxiety levels.
antioxidants.sources: Sources: Berries, dark chocolate, green tea, colorful vegetables

caffeine.title: Caffeine
caffeine.description: A stimulant that increases heart rate, triggers the release of stress hormones (cortisol, adrenaline), and can worsen anxiety symptoms. Caffeine sensitivity varies, but many with anxiety benefit from reducing or eliminating it.
caffeine.advice: Limit to <200mg/day (~2 cups coffee) or switch to green tea for gentler caffeine with L-theanine.

alcohol.title: Alcohol
alcohol.description: While it may temporarily reduce anxiety, alcohol disrupts sleep, depletes B vitamins, and causes rebound anxiety as it wears off. Chronic use worsens anxiety long-term.
alcohol.advice: Minimize or avoid alcohol, especially during high-anxiety periods.

highSugar.title: High-Sugar Foods
highSugar.description: Cause rapid blood sugar spikes followed by crashes, which trigger anxiety-like symptoms (shakiness, irritability, rapid heartbeat). High sugar intake is linked to increased anxiety.
highSugar.advice: Avoid candy, soda, baked goods; choose whole fruits instead.

processed.title: Processed Foods
processed.description: High in trans fats, artificial additives, and refined carbs that promote inflammation and blood sugar instability—both worsen anxiety.
processed.advice: Choose whole, unprocessed foods whenever possible.

sodium.title: High-Sodium Foods
sodium.description: Excessive salt can raise blood pressure and exacerbate physical anxiety symptoms. Many processed foods contain hidden sodium.
sodium.advice: Limit processed meats, canned soups, fast food; use herbs and spices for flavor instead.

findings.magnesium: Magnesium supplementation reduces subjective anxiety (multiple RCTs)
findings.omega3: Omega-3 fatty acids decrease anxiety symptoms (meta-analysis, 2018)
findings.probiotics: Probiotics reduce anxiety via gut-brain axis (emerging evidence)
findings.mediterranean: Mediterranean diet associated with lower anxiety rates

items.chicken: Grilled chicken with brown rice and sautéed spinach

items.stirfry: Stir-fried tofu with vegetables over quinoa

items.golden: Warm golden milk (turmeric, ginger, almond milk, honey)

focus.title: Foods for Focus & Cognitive Function
focus.metaDescription: Foods that improve focus and concentration. Learn about nutrients for ADHD, brain-healthy meals, protein-rich breakfasts, and cognitive performance.
focus.disclaimer: This information is educational and not a substitute for professional medical advice. Nutrition strategies can support focus and cognitive function, but ADHD and attention difficulties require comprehensive treatment. Consult your healthcare provider.

intro.p1: Brain-healthy nutrition is essential for optimal focus, concentration, and cognitive performance. Certain foods support neurotransmitter production, improve blood flow to the brain, and provide sustained energy without crashes—all critical for attention and executive function.
intro.p2: For those with ADHD, nutrition cannot replace medication or behavioral therapy, but it can significantly enhance treatment effectiveness and reduce symptoms.

fattyFish.title: Fatty Fish
fattyFish.description: Salmon, sardines, anchovies, mackerel are the richest source of DHA, an omega-3 fatty acid that makes up 40% of brain cell membranes. DHA is critical for cognitive function, and low levels are linked to ADHD symptoms.

eggs.title: Eggs
eggs.description: Contain choline, a nutrient essential for producing acetylcholine—a neurotransmitter crucial for memory and focus. Eggs also provide high-quality protein for sustained energy.

blueberries.title: Blueberries
blueberries.description: Packed with antioxidants (flavonoids) that cross the blood-brain barrier, improving communication between brain cells and enhancing memory and cognitive processing.
blueberries.serving: ½-1 cup daily, fresh or frozen.

nuts.title: Nuts (Walnuts, Almonds)
nuts.description: Rich in vitamin E, omega-3s, and magnesium—all support brain health and protect against cognitive decline. Walnuts specifically improve working memory.
nuts.serving: A handful (1 oz) as a snack or added to meals.

greenTea.title: Green Tea
greenTea.description: Contains L-theanine plus moderate caffeine—a combination that promotes calm, focused alertness without the jitters. L-theanine increases alpha brain waves associated with relaxed concentration.
greenTea.serving: 1-2 cups daily, especially mid-morning or afternoon.

beets.title: Beets
beets.description: High in nitrates that improve blood flow to the brain, enhancing oxygen delivery and cognitive performance. Studies show beets improve reaction time and decision-making.
beets.serving: Include in salads, juices, or roasted as a side dish.

darkChocolate.title: Dark Chocolate
darkChocolate.description: Contains flavonoids, caffeine, and theobromine that enhance focus, mood, and alertness. Choose 70%+ cocoa for maximum brain benefits and minimal sugar.

wholeGrains.title: Whole Grains
wholeGrains.description: Oats, quinoa, brown rice provide steady glucose to the brain (the brain's primary fuel source). Complex carbs prevent blood sugar crashes that impair concentration.
wholeGrains.serving: Choose whole grains over refined grains for sustained focus.

omega3.title: Omega-3 Fatty Acids (DHA & EPA)
omega3.description: DHA is essential for brain structure and function. Research shows omega-3 supplementation improves attention, reduces hyperactivity, and enhances cognitive performance in ADHD.
omega3.sources: Sources: Fatty fish, walnuts, flaxseeds, chia seeds, algae oil (vegan)

bVitamins.title: B Vitamins (B6, B12, Folate)
bVitamins.description: Critical for producing dopamine and norepinephrine—neurotransmitters that regulate attention, motivation, and executive function. Deficiencies worsen ADHD symptoms.
bVitamins.sources: Sources: Eggs, poultry, fish, leafy greens, legumes, fortified grains

iron.title: Iron
iron.description: Transports oxygen to the brain and is involved in dopamine production. Low iron (even without anemia) is linked to ADHD symptoms, especially inattention and fatigue.
iron.sources: Sources: Red meat, poultry, fish, lentils, spinach, fortified cereals

zinc.title: Zinc
zinc.description: Regulates dopamine function and is often low in individuals with ADHD. Zinc supplementation may enhance stimulant medication effectiveness.
zinc.sources: Sources: Oysters, beef, pumpkin seeds, cashews, chickpeas

protein.title: Protein (Amino Acids)
protein.description: Amino acids like tyrosine and tryptophan are precursors to dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin. Protein at breakfast is especially important for sustained focus and reducing impulsivity.
protein.sources: Sources: Eggs, Greek yogurt, lean meats, fish, tofu, legumes, nuts

choline.title: Choline
choline.description: Essential for producing acetylcholine, which supports memory, learning, and attention. Choline is particularly important during brain development but benefits adults too.
choline.sources: Sources: Eggs (especially yolks), liver, salmon, broccoli, Brussels sprouts

simpleSugars.title: Simple Sugars & Refined Carbohydrates
simpleSugars.description: Cause rapid blood sugar spikes followed by crashes, which impair concentration, increase hyperactivity, and worsen impulsivity. Consistent blood sugar is essential for focus.
simpleSugars.advice: Avoid candy, soda, white bread, pastries; choose whole grains and pair carbs with protein.

additives.title: Artificial Additives & Food Dyes
additives.description: Some studies suggest artificial colors (Red 40, Yellow 5, Yellow 6) and preservatives may worsen hyperactivity in sensitive children, though research is mixed. The Feingold Diet eliminates these additives.
additives.advice: Consider eliminating for 2-4 weeks to see if symptoms improve; choose whole, unprocessed foods.

caffeine.title: Excessive Caffeine
caffeine.description: While moderate caffeine can improve focus (especially paired with L-theanine in green tea), excessive amounts cause jitteriness, anxiety, and sleep disruption—all worsen ADHD symptoms.
caffeine.advice: Limit to <200mg/day; avoid caffeine after 2 PM to protect sleep.

skippingMeals.title: Skipping Meals
skippingMeals.description: Missing meals causes blood sugar drops that significantly impair concentration, working memory, and impulse control. Breakfast is especially critical for morning focus.
skippingMeals.advice: Eat regular meals every 3-4 hours; include protein and complex carbs.

allergens.title: High-Allergen Foods (If Sensitive)
allergens.description: Some individuals with ADHD have undiagnosed food sensitivities (dairy, gluten, soy) that worsen symptoms. This is not true for everyone but worth exploring if symptoms persist.
allergens.advice: Work with a healthcare provider to identify potential sensitivities through elimination diet.

findings.omega3: Omega-3 supplementation improves ADHD symptoms (multiple meta-analyses)
findings.protein: Protein-rich breakfast improves attention and reduces hyperactivity
findings.minerals: Iron and zinc deficiencies associated with ADHD severity
findings.mediterranean: Mediterranean diet linked to better cognitive function
findings.elimination: Elimination diets may help subset of individuals with food sensitivities

supplements.title: Supplements & Nutrients for Mental Health
supplements.metaDescription: Comprehensive guide to supplements for mental health: omega-3, vitamin D, magnesium, probiotics. Evidence levels, dosages, safety, and quality considerations.

safetyAlert.title: Important Safety Information
safetyAlert.text: Always consult your healthcare provider before starting any supplement. Supplements can interact with medications, cause side effects, and may not be appropriate for everyone. This information is educational only and not medical advice.

intro.p1: Supplements can play a supportive role in mental health treatment, but they should complement—not replace—a healthy diet, therapy, and prescribed medications. While some supplements have strong research support, the industry is largely unregulated, making quality and safety critical considerations.
intro.p2: Work with your healthcare provider to determine which supplements, if any, are appropriate for your individual needs, medications, and health conditions.

omega3.title: Omega-3 Fish Oil (EPA & DHA)
omega3.intro: Omega-3 fatty acids, particularly EPA (eicosapentaenoic acid) and DHA (docosahexaenoic acid), have the most robust research support for mental health.

benefits.title: Mental Health Benefits:
benefits.depression: Depression: Multiple meta-analyses show EPA-rich formulas reduce depression symptoms
benefits.adhd: ADHD: Improves attention and reduces hyperactivity in children and adults
benefits.anxiety: Anxiety: May reduce anxiety symptoms, especially in those with high inflammation

dosage.title: Recommended Dosage:
dosage.text: 1000-2000mg combined EPA+DHA daily. For depression, higher EPA ratios (EPA:DHA 2:1 or higher) may be more effective.

items.certified: Check for IFOS (International Fish Oil Standards) or USP certification
items.storage: Refrigerate after opening to prevent oxidation

safety.title: Safety:
safety.text: Generally safe. May cause fishy aftertaste, upset stomach. High doses (>3g/day) may thin blood—consult doctor if on blood thinners.

vitaminD.title: Vitamin D
vitaminD.intro: Vitamin D deficiency is extremely common and strongly linked to depression, seasonal affective disorder (SAD), and cognitive decline.

benefits.title: Mental Health Benefits:
benefits.depression: Depression: Deficiency associated with depression; supplementation improves symptoms in deficient individuals
benefits.sad: Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD): May reduce winter depression symptoms
benefits.cognitive: Cognitive Function: Supports brain health and may reduce dementia risk

dosage.title: Recommended Dosage:
dosage.text: 1000-2000 IU daily for maintenance. Test your blood levels first—optimal range is 30-50 ng/mL. Higher doses may be needed to correct deficiency.

items.type: Vitamin D3 (cholecalciferol) is more effective than D2
items.absorption: Take with a meal containing fat for better absorption
items.combine: Combine with magnesium and vitamin K2 for optimal metabolism

safety.title: Safety:
safety.text: Safe up to 4000 IU/day for most adults. Excessive doses can cause toxicity. Regular blood testing recommended.

bComplex.title: B-Complex Vitamins
bComplex.intro: B vitamins (B6, B12, folate) are essential for neurotransmitter production and are often depleted in depression and chronic stress.

benefits.title: Mental Health Benefits:
benefits.general: B6, B12, Folate: Support serotonin, dopamine, and norepinephrine production
benefits.b12: B12 Deficiency: Causes depression, fatigue, and cognitive impairment (common in vegans/vegetarians)

dosage.title: Recommended Dosage:
dosage.text: B-complex containing 100% RDA of each B vitamin. For deficiency, higher therapeutic doses under medical supervision.

items.medications: Those taking metformin or acid-reducing medications (interfere with B12 absorption)

safety.title: Safety:
safety.text: B vitamins are water-soluble and generally safe. Excess amounts are excreted in urine.

magnesium.title: Magnesium
magnesium.intro: Magnesium is involved in over 300 biochemical reactions, including those regulating mood and stress response. Deficiency is common and linked to anxiety and depression.

benefits.title: Mental Health Benefits:
benefits.anxiety: Anxiety: Natural muscle relaxant; calms nervous system
benefits.depression: Depression: Some studies show magnesium reduces depressive symptoms
benefits.sleep: Sleep: Improves sleep quality (especially magnesium glycinate)

dosage.title: Recommended Dosage:
dosage.text: 200-400mg daily. Best taken in divided doses with food.

items.glycinate: Magnesium Glycinate: Best for anxiety, sleep, gentle on stomach
items.citrate: Magnesium Citrate: Good absorption, may have laxative effect
items.threonate: Magnesium L-Threonate: Crosses blood-brain barrier, supports cognition

safety.title: Safety:
safety.text: Generally safe. High doses may cause diarrhea. Avoid if you have kidney disease. May interact with certain medications.

probiotics.title: Probiotics
probiotics.intro: The gut-brain axis is a major area of mental health research. Specific probiotic strains produce neurotransmitters and regulate the stress response via the vagus nerve.

benefits.title: Mental Health Benefits:
benefits.anxietyDepression: Anxiety & Depression: Certain strains (Lactobacillus, Bifidobacterium) may reduce symptoms
benefits.stress: Stress Resilience: May reduce cortisol and improve stress response
benefits.gut: Gut Health: Supports overall digestive health

dosage.title: Recommended Dosage:
dosage.text: 10-50 billion CFU daily from multi-strain formula. Refrigerated probiotics tend to have higher viability.

safety.title: Safety:
safety.text: Generally safe. May cause gas or bloating initially. Those with compromised immune systems should consult a doctor first.

same.title: SAMe (S-Adenosyl Methionine)
same.intro: SAMe is a compound naturally produced in the body that supports neurotransmitter function and has antidepressant properties.

benefits.title: Mental Health Benefits:
benefits.depression: Depression: Multiple studies show SAMe as effective as some antidepressants
benefits.onset: Onset: May work faster than SSRIs (1-2 weeks vs 4-6 weeks)

dosage.title: Recommended Dosage:
dosage.text: 400-1600mg daily in divided doses. Start low and increase gradually.

items.supervision: Medical Supervision Required: Can interact with antidepressants
items.bipolar: Not for Bipolar: May trigger mania in bipolar disorder
items.quality: Quality Matters: Enteric-coated formulas more stable

safety.title: Safety:
safety.text: Generally well-tolerated but can cause GI upset, anxiety, or insomnia. Do not combine with antidepressants without medical supervision.

lTheanine.title: L-Theanine
lTheanine.intro: An amino acid found in green tea that promotes relaxation without sedation by increasing alpha brain waves.

benefits.title: Mental Health Benefits:
benefits.anxiety: Anxiety: Reduces acute anxiety and promotes calm focus
benefits.focus: Focus: Paired with caffeine, improves attention and reduces jitters
benefits.sleep: Sleep Quality: May improve sleep without causing drowsiness during the day

dosage.title: Recommended Dosage:
dosage.text: 100-200mg as needed, 1-3 times daily. Often combined with caffeine (1:2 ratio) for focused energy.

safety.title: Safety:
safety.text: Extremely safe with minimal side effects. No known drug interactions. Non-habit forming.

stJohnsWort.title: St. John's Wort
stJohnsWort.description: Evidence for depression but serious drug interactions. St. John's Wort reduces effectiveness of many medications including birth control, blood thinners, and antidepressants. Can cause serotonin syndrome if combined with SSRIs.
stJohnsWort.warning: Only use under medical supervision. Never combine with prescription antidepressants.

highDoseVitamins.title: High-Dose Vitamins
highDoseVitamins.description: Mega-doses of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K) can accumulate and cause toxicity. More is not better—follow recommended dosages.

herbal.title: Unregulated Herbal Supplements
herbal.description: Many herbal supplements lack quality control, may be contaminated with heavy metals, and have inconsistent potency. Stick with third-party tested brands.

kava.title: Kava
kava.description: While effective for anxiety, kava has been linked to liver damage in some individuals. Avoid if you have liver disease or take medications affecting the liver.

fdaRegulation.title: FDA Regulation
fdaRegulation.text: Supplements are NOT FDA-regulated like medications. Manufacturers are not required to prove safety or effectiveness before selling. This makes quality control critical.

thirdParty.title: Third-Party Testing
thirdParty.intro: Look for these certifications on supplement labels:

items.usp: USP Verified: Purity, potency, and quality tested
items.nsf: NSF Certified: Independent testing for contaminants
items.ifos: IFOS (Fish Oil): International Fish Oil Standards

interactions.title: Medication Interactions
interactions.intro: Always tell your healthcare provider about all supplements you take. Common interactions include:

items.kidneyLiver: Liver or kidney disease (certain supplements contraindicated)
items.bipolar: Bipolar disorder (some supplements may trigger mania)

bottomLine.title: The Bottom Line
bottomLine.text: Supplements can be valuable tools in mental health treatment, but they work best as part of a comprehensive approach that includes therapy, lifestyle changes, and—when appropriate—medication. Always prioritize quality, work with your healthcare provider, and remember that no supplement can replace professional treatment for mental health conditions.
